facts.text: The appellant was a Sub Inspector of Police serving in the Enforcement Branch of the Calcutta Police on 20th May 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was a Sub Inspector of Police serving in the Enforcement Branch of the Calcutta Police on 20th May 1951, when he was ordered by S. Mukherji, Deputy Commissioner of Police, Enforcement Branch, to search a house at 13/2 Sir Guru Das Road, in Kankurgachi Basti.

facts.text: On 20th May 1951, the appellant was ordered by S. Mukherji, Deputy Commissioner of Police, Enforcement Branch, to search a house at 13/2 Sir Guru Das Road, in Kankurgachi Basti.

anchor.surface_text: when he was ordered by S. Mukherji, Deputy Commissioner of Police, Enforcement Branch, to search a house at 13/2 Sir Guru Das Road, in Kankurgachi Basti. He alleged that the search companycluded at 6-30 a.m., and, thereafter, he had gone to take tea with the permission and or knowledge of his immediate superior Sub Inspector S. Bose.

facts.text: The search concluded at 6:30 a.m. on 20th May 1951, after which the appellant went to take tea with permission or knowledge of Sub Inspector S. Bose.

anchor.surface_text: He alleged that the search companycluded at 6-30 a.m., and, thereafter, he had gone to take tea with the permission and or knowledge of his immediate superior Sub Inspector S. Bose. We fail to understand what the appellant exactly meant when he swore, in his affidavit, that he had gone to take tea with the permission and or knowledge of his immediate superior officer.

facts.text: The appellant was met by Assistant Commissioner of Police Ataur Rahman while returning from tea, at a distance of about one furlong from the place of duty.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant alleged that he was met by the Assistant Commissioner of Police. Ataur Rahman, when he was companying back, after taking tea, to the place of search, but he was still at a distance of about one furlong from the assigned place of duty.

facts.text: Assistant Commissioner Ataur Rahman charged the appellant with dereliction of duties, disobedience of order to remain at post, perfunctory search, disloyalty, and giving information to offenders.

anchor.surface_text: He alleged that the Assistant Commissioner charged the appel- lant, immediately on accosting him, with dereliction of his duties, with disobedience of the order to remain at the post of his duty, with carrying out the search perfunctorily, with disloyalty and giving away of information of proposed searches to offending members of the public so that the purpose of the search, which was said to be detection of spurious ration cards, may be defeated.

facts.text: The appellant was immediately suspended and Ataur Rahman was appointed Enquiry Officer.

anchor.surface_text: It was stated that the appellant was immediately suspended and the Assistant Commissioner Ataur Rahman was appointed the Enquiry Officer.

facts.text: The appellant alleged violations of Police Regulations in Bengal, including not making charges clear and not affording opportunity to defend or cross-examine.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also alleged certain violations of the rules under the Police Regulations in Bengal, mainly by number making the charges or their particulars clear to him and by number affording due opportunity to the appellant to offer his defence or to cross-examine witnesses.

facts.text: The departmental proceeding resulted from bias and ill-will of Deputy Commissioner S. Mukherji against the appellant due to proceedings against antisocial elements friendly with Mukherji.

anchor.surface_text: Furthermore, the appellant alleged that the proceeding was the result of the bias and ill-will of Deputy Commissioner of Police, S. Mukherji, against him, because the appellant had taken some proceedings against antisocial elements who were, according to him, friendly with the Deputy Commissioner of Police.

facts.text: Appellant was harassed by false criminal proceedings under Essential Supplies Act and Section 124-A IPC in October 1951 due to grudge of S. Mukherji.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also assorted that he was harassed by false and frivolous criminal proceedings under the Essential Supplies Act and under Section 124-A I.P.C. in October, 1951, due to this grudge of the Deputy Commissioner against him.

facts.text: Appellant was served with show cause notices at two stages, produced evidence considered relevant, cross-examined five prosecution witnesses, examined seven defence witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had, however, been duly served with show cause numberices at two stages and had produced evidence which the Enquirying Officer companysidered relevant. Permission to call other evidence, companysidered irrelevant and to cross- examine some witnesses, who had number been relied upon by the prosecution, was number given. The five prosecution witnesses relied upon by the prosecution were cross-examined by the appellant. He had also examined seven defence witnesses.

facts.text: Appellant was dismissed from Police Force by Deputy Commissioner S. Mukherji on 1 August 1951.

anchor.surface_text: After the report of the Enquirying Officer against the appellant, he was dismissed from the Police Force by the Deputy Commissioner of Police, S. Mukherji, on 1-8-1951.

facts.text: Appellant's appeal to Inspector General of Police was dismissed on 27 October 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal preferred by the appellant to the Inspector General of Police was also dismissed on 27-10-1951.

facts.text: Appellant submitted a memorial to Government of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the petitioner had submitted a memorial to the Govt. of West Bengal.

facts.text: Appellant went to Andaman Islands in November 1952 fearing harassment by Police.

anchor.surface_text: He also stated that fearing harassment and oppression by the Police he went away to the Andaman Islands in November, 1952.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Article 226 on 9 September 1953.

anchor.surface_text: He had filed his petition under Article 226 of the Constitution on 9th September, 1953.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court Single Judge dismissed the petition on 11 September 1957 on grounds of inordinate delay and failure to raise jurisdiction objection earlier.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants petition was dismissed on 11-9-1957 by a learned Judge of the Calcutta High Court on two preliminary grounds firstly, that there was inordinate delay on the part of the appellant in approaching the High Court and, secondly, that the objection to the jurisdiction of the dismissing authority, the Deputy Commissioner of Police, was number taken, in the companyrse of Departmental proceedings, so that it companyld number be allowed to be raised before the High Court for the first time.

facts.text: Single Judge held Deputy Commissioner had power to dismiss as same rank as appointing authority, and dismissal confirmed by IGP; no substance in malafides plea.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge held that the Deputy. Commissioner of Police seemed to be of the same grade and status as the Principal of the Police Training School, Sharda, with the rank of a Superintendent, and who had appointed the appellant, so that there was numberviolation of Article 311   1   of the Constitution. And, in any case, the dismissal was companyfirmed by the higher authority of the Inspector General.

facts.text: Division Bench of Calcutta High Court dismissed appeal on 14 May 1963 principally on ground of inordinate delay.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION C. A. No. 1162 of 1967. Appeal by certificate under Article 133 of the Constitution of India from the judgment and order dated 14th May 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Order No. 44 of 1958.

facts.text: Division Bench found rules of natural justice violated but delay fatal; rejected explanation of delay.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal from the decision of the learned Single Judge, a Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court dismissed it principally on the ground of inordinate delay despite the fact that the Division Bench was disposed to hold that rules of natural justice had been violated in the Departmental Enquiry against the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by certificate under Article 133, C.A. No. 1162 of 1967.

Varma the Writ Petition could have been dismissed on the ground that it is not the practice of Courts to decide such disputed questions of fact in proceedings under Article 226 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Delay unreasonable even if within suit limitation; distinguish Bhailal as disputed facts involved.

arguments.claim: Laches bars mandamus; public interest requires promptness for public servants.

holdings.text: It is not the practice of Courts to decide such disputed questions of fact in proceedings under Article 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, think that, quite apart from the ground of delay in filing the Writ Petition, the assertions and counter- assertions made on merits were of such a nature that, in accordance with the rule laid down by this Court in Union of India v. T. R. Varma 1  the Writ Petition could have been dismissed on the ground that it is not the practice of Courts to decide such disputed questions of fact in proceedings under Article 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assertions and counter-assertions on merits are disputed questions of fact; follows Supreme Court precedent in Union of India v. T.R. Varma.

holdings.text: The discretion of the learned Single Judge and the Division Bench with regard to a delay which defeated the petitioner's right to discretionary relief under Article 226 could not be interfered with.

anchor.surface_text: At any rate, we do not think that the discretion of the learned Single Judge and the Division Bench, with regard to a delay which defeated the petitioners right to a discretionary relief, could be interfered with by us in this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inordinate delay rejected by both High Court benches; explanations disbelieved; no basis to interfere.

holdings.text: The actual violation of the order of the Deputy Commissioner was detected by other officers.

anchor.surface_text: But we find that the actual violation of the order of the Deputy Commissioner was detected by other officers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows detection by other officers, not solely by Deputy Commissioner.

holdings.text: The Enquiring Officer merely collected evidence against the appellant and made a report; it could more properly be said that he and not the Deputy Commissioner of Police was the accusing officer.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Enquiring Officer had made certain charges against the appellant when he found him returning from somewhere, one furlong removed from the place where, according to orders given, the appellant should have been present then, yet, he had merely collected evidence against the appellant and made a report.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiring Officer confronted appellant but only gathered evidence and reported; not accuser in sense disqualifying punishment authority.

holdings.text: The mere fact that the Deputy Commissioner's orders were alleged to have been disobeyed did not make him a complainant and a witness.

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that the Deputy Commissioners orders were alleged to have been disobeyed did not make him a complainant and a witness.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issuing order does not automatically make authority a complainant or witness barring punishment.

holdings.text: Questions whether there was bias, ill-will, malafides, or due opportunity to be heard or produce evidence in departmental proceedings are so largely questions of fact that it is difficult to decide them merely on conflicting assertions in affidavits.

anchor.surface_text: Nonetheless, the questions whether there was bias, ill-will, malafides, or a due opportunity to be heard or to produce evidence, given in the course of departmental proceedings, are so largely questions of fact that it is difficult to decide them merely on conflicting assertions made by affidavits given by the two sides.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nature of issues involves factual disputes unsuitable for resolution on affidavits alone in writ proceedings.

holdings.text: The rule that delay defeats the rights of a party to seek redress by means of prerogative writ under Article 226 is not abrogated merely because the period of limitation for a civil suit would not have expired.

anchor.surface_text: If this is the position with regard to the petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution, we do not think that the rule that delay defeats the rights of a party to seek redress, by means of prerogative Writ under Article 226 of the Constitution, could be held to be abrogated merely because, if the claim had been brought in a Civil Court, the period of limitation would not have expired.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing State of MP v Bhailal Bhai; Art 226 discretion considers delay independently; analogous to Art 32; disputed facts make delay fatal unlike void tax cases.

holdings.text: There are good grounds for refusal to exercise discretion to interfere with the impugned order of dismissal due to laches, public interest, and need for promptness by public servants seeking mandamus for reinstatement.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Laches bars mandamus per Halsbury and Ferris; public policy demands promptness to avoid unnecessary payment to non-serving employee; motives suspect after delay.

precedents.citation: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Bhailal Ors 1   at page 273- 274

anchor.surface_text: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Bhailal Ors 1   at page 273- 274  It appears to us however that the maximum period fixed by the legislature as the time within which the relief by a suit in a civil Court must be brought may ordinarily be taken to be a reasonable standard by which delay in seeking remedy under Article 226 can be mea-

precedents.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Bhailal
precedents.cited_proposition: maximum period fixed by the legislature as the time within which the relief by a suit in a civil Court must be brought may ordinarily be taken to be a reasonable standard by which delay in seeking remedy under Article 226 can be measured
precedents.cited_holding: if the aggrieved person came to the High Court within the period of limitation prescribed for ordinary suits for challenging an illegal exaction under a void order, the writ could issue

precedents.citation: Union of India v. T. R. Varma 1

anchor.surface_text: Union of India v. T. R. Varma 1  the Writ Petition could have been dismissed on the ground that it is not the practice of Courts to decide such disputed questions of fact in proceedings under Article 226 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Union of India v. T. R. Varma
precedents.cited_proposition: it is not the practice of Courts to decide such disputed questions of fact in proceedings under Article 226 of the Constitution

precedents.citation: Chandra Bhushan Anr. v. Deputy Director of Consolidation  Regional  U.P. Ors.  2

anchor.surface_text: Chandra Bhushan Anr. v. Deputy Director of Consolidation  Regional  U.P. Ors.  2  , where this Court has set aside an order of the Allahabad High Court dismissing a Writ Petition in limine by exalting a rule of practice into a rule of limitation so that a few days delay, shown to have been caused by the closing of the office of the Court for Diwali holidays was not condoned by the Allahabad High Court.

precedents.case_name: Chandra Bhushan v. Deputy Director of Consolidation
precedents.cited_proposition: a few days delay caused by holidays should be condoned and writ petition not dismissed in limine

precedents.citation: Rabindra Nath Bose Ors. v. Union of India Ors.  1

anchor.surface_text: Rabindra Nath Bose Ors. v. Union of India Ors.  1  was also referred to in the course of arguments, although this case relates to the exercise of the powers of this Court under Article 32 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Rabindra Nath Bose v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: no relief should be given to petitioners who without any reasonable explanation, approach this Court under Article 32 of the Constitution after inordinate delay

anchor.surface_text: We think that there are good grounds here for a refusal to exercise the discretion to interfere with the impugned order of dismissal. The result is that we dismiss this appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; no interference with the High Court's dismissal of the writ petition challenging the order of dismissal from service; appellant denied reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, think that, quite apart from the ground of delay in filing the Writ Petition, the assertions and counter- assertions made on merits were of such a nature that, in accordance with the rule laid down by this Court in Union of India v. T. R. Varma 1  the Writ Petition could have been dismissed on the ground that it is not the practice of Courts to decide such disputed questions of fact in proceedings under Article 226 of the Constitution.
We think that there are good grounds here for a refusal to exercise the discretion to interfere with the impugned order of dismissal. The result is that we dismiss this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: At any rate, we do not think that the discretion of the learned Single Judge and the Division Bench, with regard to a delay which defeated the petitioners right to a discretionary relief, could be interfered with by us in this case.
We think that there are good grounds here for a refusal to exercise the discretion to interfere with the impugned order of dismissal. The result is that we dismiss this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We think that there are good grounds here for a refusal to exercise the discretion to interfere with the impugned order of dismissal. The result is that we dismiss this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: If this is the position with regard to the petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution, we do not think that the rule that delay defeats the rights of a party to seek redress, by means of prerogative Writ under Article 226 of the Constitution, could be held to be abrogated merely because, if the claim had been brought in a Civil Court, the period of limitation would not have expired.
We think that there are good grounds here for a refusal to exercise the discretion to interfere with the impugned order of dismissal. The result is that we dismiss this appeal.
